reviewText:
Carrier Command: Gaea Mission is ultimately a good (not great) game that blends strategy, tactics and action, but it suffers from the most god-awful annoying campaign I think I have ever played.

You'll hear a lot about the bad bad BAD script and voice acting, but the campaign is terribly paced too, being, as it seems it was intended, a very, very long tutorial for the Strategy Game option. Having said that, I persevered with the Campaign, and after you take Fulcrum and push into the enemy's territory, which is around the same time you unlock missiles for your Mantas‚Äîand around the time the AI starts pushing back!‚Äîthe game finally lives up to its promise and gets awesome.

Taking the islands become a real tactical challenge each time, and your strategy of which islands should be Production, Mining and (oh so important) Defense becomes critical to success. When you get to that point, the Campaign is actually pretty good and the game finally lives up to its potential.


Whether or not you can stick it out that long is another story...I have a LOT of love and nostalgia for Carrier Command, having played it ad nauseum on my Amiga when I was a kid, but without that good will, I'm not sure I would have had the gumption to push through the bad bad BAD start of the Campaign game. If you can, though, I think you'll find you are rewarded.


Subjective Assessment: 7/10

reviewText:
Back in 1988 a company known as Realtime Games created a game called Carrier Command for multiple home computers such as the Amiga, ZX Spectrum, and Commodore 64. A crossover between a vehicle simulation game and a real-time strategy game, players were tasked with colonizing multiple islands in an archipelago and destroy the enemy aircraft carrier before they can colonize the archipelago themselves. The game was well received receiving high marks from various publications, and gaming magazine The Games Machine even awarded it the number one game of 1988. In 2012 Bohemia Interactive released Carrier Command: Gaea Mission, a modern remake of the original Carrier Command. Did the game hold up over all these years?

For starters, I‚Äôve never played the original Carrier Command, so I can‚Äôt really compare the original to the remake.  From what I can tell, the main goal of Carrier Command‚Äôs campaign is to take control of various islands on the planetoid Taurus in a war between two factions: the United Earth Coalition and the Asian Pacific Alliance. The Campaign portion of the game starts out with you leading an attack on a moon called Taurus in an attempt to take control of it for its resources, to help sway the battle against forces who have taken over Earth. Unfortunately something goes wrong and your squadron crashes on the moon and only a few survive. From there you set out on foot with another soldier who guides you as you roam about in a FPS-style game. Your first goal is to make your way to a damaged carrier. You will venture through a very linear path with just one gun, shooting at very generic looking robots.

After this short and dull FPS sequence, I came across the first vehicle in the game. My squadmates started directing me how to control the vehicle and what I could do with it. I found that controlling it was difficult using a mouse and keyboard, so I switched over to using a game controller, where one analog stick steered and the other aimed my gun. Playing with a controller honestly felt more rewarding. Your ground vehicle‚Äôs health, fuel and ammo could be topped up by just driving up to various refilling stations shown on the map and pressing the right button. Topping off the vehicles various items is quick, which came in handy when you are on the run. You have two viewing choices when moving your vehicles: a first person or 3rd person view. I stuck mainly with the third-person camera angle because you need to see more of the surrounding area so you don‚Äôt suddenly find yourself sliding down a hill, out of control.

After becoming familiar with your new toy, you eventually make your way to the damaged carrier, dock at its side, and make your way inside. Once again you are back on foot in a short FPS segment taking out more robots. After all the robots are cleared, the surviving soldiers join you on the carrier, and you take command of the ship which turns out to be completely remote controlled, so you don‚Äôt need to leave your command chair. However, the carrier is badly damaged and in need of repair. So from your new seat you are able to remotely control the vehicle that brought you to the carrier.  You wil then drive it to the nearest island on your map to search for supplies. This is where the game‚Äôs focus shifts to the main campaign where you will be taking over various islands you come across by hacking into base computers.

I quickly found that this is not that simple because all the islands have defenses in the form of ground roaming robots, vehicles, as well as small and speedy airships. Not to mention most of the bases have gun turrets. Much of the time you will be running around activating switches to shut things down to gain access to areas and bypass enemy defences. Different islands have different properties: some have production facilities which will produce new equipment or vehicles; others are rich in resources that you need to repair your carrier and produce your equipment. There are up to 33 islands in the game all with various environments. Some can be swampy, others more temperate and others more desert-like. In the swampy areas it is really hard to control ground assaults as you slip and slide in the mud and wet grass.

This is where a real time strategy-like gameplay element comes into play as you dive deeper into the game. Some islands get tricky and require you to have more than one vehicle on the go. You can have up to four ground and four air vehicles executing orders at the same time, each equipped with various guns and devices that you produce to aid you in taking over the island in question. I found the AI for the game as a whole to be very hit or miss, with spots of brilliance followed by some completely bizarre behaviour.

Other than the main campaign, you have one other mode called ‚ÄúStrategy Game‚Äù. Here you are pitted against the computer in a large randomly-generated battle, but you have various settings at your disposal like the number of islands, enemy strength, what resources you start up with and how fast islands generate the materials you need. You can also set winning conditions too, like a number of carriers destroyed, or islands that need to be taken over. It‚Äôs a fun mode if you want to avoid the single player story and get into the thick of things quickly.

In terms of the visuals, the game is nice to look at, but nothing blew me away. Weather and environmental effects are nicely done and you can see a bit of influence from the ARMA series in it. I did experience some weird clipping issues while driving vehicles. I would be driving along and suddenly part of the screen would flash like I drove through something. The music in the game is odd. It‚Äôs very big and orchestra-sounding with a large choir, but it only plays at certain times. The rest of the time it‚Äôs just environmental sound effects mixed with sounds of vehicles and gunfire. Voiceovers from the characters work quite well, and no one seems to be overacting their roles, but as you progress through the game you do get somewhat tired of hearing what they have to say.

For a game that attempts to mix in some First Person Shooter sequences with some Real Time Strategy elements, Bohemia Interactive did a decent job. Unfortunately, the overall experience falls a little short due to some of the issues with the AI as well as the lack of any multiplayer and some technical issues.

reviewText:
A rough gem.
Could have been a new franchise ala battlefield with some more love imho, but sadly it wasn't so.
It shipped with a few annoying bugs which are mostly fixed today.
It has the occassional, though predictive, crash, however II only started to experience those during the later half of the game (after 25 hours of gameplay or so).
Pathfinding issues have mostly been resolved, with a few minor exceptions.
These issues aside, this game is totally awesome and well worth the ‚Ç¨25 it is sold for today.
I regret the fact it never got a successor, because the different concept applied in this game are quite awesome.

- Take a sip from your drink while your units do the hard work like refueling and moving to a far away position, and take control as soon as the action happens.
- Everything happens realtime. Production needs to be planned in advance because its not instantly ready (for example the production of fuel so you can travel to a different island). And although traveling to a different island does speed up time, you'll have to wait till your ship gets there. As a side effect: there is no loading screen.
- Though the amount of different units are rather limiting (though somewhat understandable considering you're commanding a carrier), there are many different upgrades to choose from.
- You'll have to take care of some of the logistics yourself, which adds to realism.

reviewText:
Think Tom Clancy's Endgame combined with Advance Wars, except you can hop into one of your units for direct control--and you will because the AI is seriously awful.

Accolades:
+ Cool premise--If Bohemia put more work into this concept it could really shine.  Island-hopping with your newly upgraded units is pretty fun.  Enemies attacking your islands add a sense of urgency to a normally slower-paced game type.

+ Easy and intuitive multitasking controls--The controls range from basic to advanced to accommodate all play styles.

+ Aircraft carrier is badass

Criticisms:

- Painfully awful forced 1st person missions in campaign mode--I don't know how any of the devs could defend these missions and say that they were fun or well-designed.  Why?  To name a few reasons:  You can't jump, you only have one gun, the autoaim is crazy, and you kill the one enemy type (in 1st person mode) 3 bullets a piece.  90% of the missions you literally just need to W+M1 to the next objective marker and you'll win--which reminds me that you can't pick a difficulty mode.  I would recommend playing the 'strategy game' mode.

- Story--You crash land on a planet and you hijack an aircraft carrier to take it over.  Good blue guys shoot red bad guys and vice versa.  They should have left it at that but the game crowbars in cut scenes of the unrelatable Lt. Australia and his inconsequential friends.

- Aforementioned AI--Unless your units severely outclass the enemies on an island, trust the AI to only take out buildings.  There seems to be no way to suit your walruses up nicely and send them into an area without taking very heavy losses.

There really could (and should!) be a lot more to this game but if you like games like Endwar, check it out.

reviewText:
I recommend but only as a curiosity on sale. This game is very different in style from almost any other (except the original). It's representative of a game genre that has never taken off because its games (Battlecruiser Millenium and the ilk) have seemed amazing in theory but never yet in execution.

The game mechanic seems sound until you realise it only takes defeating the enemy carrier once (not all that hard or satisfying) to win what could otherwise be a long drawn out strategy game. That's broken.

However, there's little cooler than watching all your walruses and mantas launch from the ship with all the picture-in-picture displays, then hooking up the land vehicles with the carry-all hook and invading an island. Very few games let you do that.

The single player mode here was ambitious but is as broken as the strategy game but for different reasons. The voice acting and character animations are painful, and the first person shooting (an aspect not present in the strategy game, sadly) is just not fun. It just doesn't feel good.

I recommend as a morbid curiosity. To see what games could be, and to demand better in future, not for any particular thing that this title does well. Don't pay full price for this though. It's good for a few hours at most (though you may find yourself losing days to it despite all that).

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, this game is of high quality and brilliant ideas. It has stunning graphic, the islands maps are so detailed and well made in order to suit vehicle gameplay that I almost feel like it would be a waste to manage all your units in the RTS map mode.

But I wouldn't recommend it to others. It's just that I found the gameplay somewhat unrewarding and repetitive. Although you got lots of weapon and modification types, the basic structure of every battle is pretty much the same. You drive your carrier to capture an island, deploy 4 Mantas (hoverplane) and 4 Walruses (armour car) with various weapon and tools and head to the command centre. You don't have any other type of units except those two.

Although the campaign start with a FPS experience, you don't get to play as foot soldiers anymore after the first level. I was expecting the player to be at least able to walk around the commanding bridge of the carrier, staring outside the window as you wait and watch your units coming home, and I was disappointed. Even though you did walk around inside the carrier in the first level.

You can't move your carrier in anyway besides the preset waypoints of warp positions. You can't direct control anything other than those 4 Mantas, 4 Walruses and a main gun on your carrier, dispite how many droids and turrets defences you own on an island and that even though you did play as a droid in the first level.

There are just too many little disappointments such as these, and too few variations or distractions to keep you entertained besides the main objective, which can be frustrating at times. The game really appeared to be an nice and huge open-world playground, but far too often I feel myself restrained in actual gameplay.

It's a well-made game coming from one of my favourite developers but IMO got loads of wasted potential. I got this game from humble bundle for a few dollars, along with ARMA series I believe, and it's well-worth it. But the full price of $32.99, I don't think so.

I really wanted to like this game but it would let me :(
Reloading a classic RTS-Action blend seems like a great idea to start with and the scenario with the aircraft carrier is kinda cool.

However Bohemia really nailed it to ruin it all with the horrendous AI and the god awful pathfinding. The developers seemed to have missed the point that they could actually design the game so it would work properly. At times u can tell that it's not a matter of lacking IT skills but the lack of inspiration and distance to their game. Sometimes u feel like no1 ever playtested this during development.
There's a ton of things that they simply should have left out (pretty effortless to do).

The land unit: a boat-tank kinda hybrid with custom loadout. Would be a fun idea if it wouldnt have a god awful pathfinding and a handling like a wobbly shopping cart. If this thing would be a hovercraft it wouldnt get stuck on the randomly gnerated terain geometry. This coulda been implemented easily and would solve a huge ammount of issues. Why does it have to have wheels in first place if it clearly conflicts with the gameplay.
Terrain: Enemy Unit Wreckage blocks the paths and  the AI can't react to it ...absolutely idiotic design,,,just unspawn the stuff or make it non collision.
Different environmental conditions...Disastrous..some of the arctic islands are covered in snowstorms wich totally obstruct the vision. Then theres muddy terain wich is horrible to maneuver and serves no purpose .
The placing of the structures is annoying in most of the missions u have to cruise around the whole island to deactivate stuff wich is located on top of hills that take ages for the units to get up to, just to get shot to pieces since they often waste all their ammo on enemies they can't hit anyway.
The units will also nonsensicly burn all their fuel by circling each other either to get unstuck or even when actually supposed to be idling in place^^
Every structure has to be approached really closely to activate...yet again simply impossible for the AI to do properly ..You have to micro manage every move of each vehicle just to refill stuff.

This reults in overall extremely slow gameplay, Everything seems like an unnecessary drag and u find yourself save-scumming all the time just to avoid all the AI issues. The FPS parts are simply hillariously bad and extremely generic. The writing is plain stupid and illogical.
I heard that the game is supposed to get better when u made it past the first 15 hours or so..(i have a hard time to believe that due to the AI problems tho) ...that might be true but noone in their sane mind has that much patience to get through this cheese up to that point.

The only thing wich really makes this a cool experience is the fact that u got alot of time to think about all the flaws.

At times it's grotesquely bad.. i wonder why i actually play it, think it has a B-Movie charme in a way.

reviewText:
This game is very much a diamond in the rough. It has a ton of rough edges and desperately needs more developer attention, but it has tons of potential and I've (mostly) enjoyed my time with it.

The concept of the game is amazing and mostly works, it's awesome to be able to seamlessly switch between FPS and RTS controls. Unfortunately the AI for your units is pretty bad so you'll have to micromanage them (and frequently take direct control) so they don't get stuck and killed. The poor AI is probably the single biggest issue with the game in its current state.

I found the most effective strategy to be to order my units to move to a staging area and take control of one unit at a time to manually chip away at the enemy defenses, retreating after taking too much damage and switching to the next unit and ordering the damaged unit to head back to the carrier for repairs.

One area that I would like to see improved is the addition of controllable ground troops for capturing objectives (remote control robotic infantry is available in the campaign for certain scripted missions but is unavailable outside of that) that you would ferry in using the APCs. More variety of vehicle weapons and attachments would be great as well.

That said, the current asking price is too high for this game. It is still a beta, don't buy at the $30 asking price, wait for a deep discount (the happen semi frequently) and pick it up then, otherwise you will likely be disappointed due to all the rough edges.

reviewText:
I have many fond memories of this game's progenitor when I played it on my beloved Amiga A500. The graphics were simple, but functional for the experience of tactical and strategic gameplay. The entire premise of the game was almost like a naval chess battle. When I heard there was a remake in the works I did have expectations that the core of the game would still be there, but in a very modern wrapping. The carrier itself has visually transformed and like all the visuals, is very impressive. The audio is good too, but the execution of this games core is poor. Blending first person shooter elements into the game helps take the stale out of being locked into vehicles, but there's no multiplayer to really validate it. The need to be moving in and out of vehicles and structures feels like a bolt on to a RTS game.
Actual vehicle combat is good enough, The AI is thin, pathing for friendly vehicles is often poor, and I've had to manually retrieve a fair few Walrus that got themselves trapped. The enemy doesn't show a great deal more sense, and the challenge they present isn't in their tactics, but their numbers and loadout as you progress through the campaign. I was aching to get my carrier toe-to-toe with the enemy's. I loved brining down the ACC Omega on the original version, but the naval combat is almost pointless, it's mostly defending your own ship from island defences and when you do finally meet your nautical nemesis, you feel like a bug on a windshield. (The originals enemy carrier had weaknesses, the modern version only becomes vunerable after a certain point, beware of this)
The two modes of play differ mainly in that one has specific story based missions and goals in a near linear campaign format. The other is more likened to the original, though it's best to point out here that it is a LOT slower leaving an imprssion that playing through it will be an immense chore.
This game would have flourished as a multiplayer experience with players piloting or on foot, either in direct engagement or attacking/sabotaging supply lines. I had fun, but couldn't help feeling that they just didn't really go the distance with Carrier Command they could have.
Good - Solid visuals, good management and vehicle combat can be a lotta fun.
Bad - Cardboard thin depth of play and no multiplayer (and no real excuse for its absence)

reviewText:
Carrier Command: Gaea mission is a Real-Time Strategy game that also allows you to jump into either your air or amphibious land vehicles to capture islands with the goal being either to capture every island on the map and/or destroy your enemy's carrier, or at least that's how I understand it 6 hours in.

Like the start of a rollercoaster, you'll start to anticipate how much fun you're going to have with this game: a tech tree (albeit randomized), logistics management, the cameras that show you what your unit sees.  Then the cart flies off the tracks when the Tropic Thunder A.I. that manages your pathfinding clashes with the enemy's Skynet's A.I..  Units equipped with grenade launchers will stand still point their guns in the air upon receiving a command to attack a structure, or straight up murder your own carrier if you deploy them to chase a nearby enemy unit.  Thankfully, the air unit's A.I. is on point, and probably better than your own flight skills.

I would be amazed if you could lose an island at all to the A.I., as conquering an enemy island requires you to do a side mission, including fuse-boxing scramblers so that your units can reach the command center, or fuse-boxing firewalls so that capturing a center doesn't take five years.  It's 50/50 that your unit will reach the area and activate the point without getting stuck on a rock or tree.  Units even get tripped up on things as nebulous as water on the main map screen.  By the time you've spent half an hour taking an island the size of five minutes, the game crashes on the very next move you make.  If you won't save your money, at least save your game after every conquest you make here.

The game makes other bizzare decisions: You aren't told how long an area you've captured will be ready for production.  You can't speed up time outside of running out of gas and trying to gun it to an island anyway.  An invisible tech tree that you make random progress in when you capture an island or click a factory.

The other reviews here are accurate.  I'm not deterred by a few glitches here and there, but this game made me throw in the towel.

I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #32 - Command Carrier: Gaea Mission

This is another example of a very mediocre game from Bohemia Interactive.  The production values are not that great.  The graphics aren't bad, and the sound effects were alright, but honestly I could have just played this with the sound off and been just as happy not to listen to anymore of the voice acting or music.

The opening of the campaign just plays like a straight up sci-fi based shooter with some dull characters and story.  But eventually you get command of a carrier, and the game morphs into a real time strategy.  I did not get very far into the strategy part of the game, so I may be missing some of the better parts of the game.   But even in the short time I did play, I could already get a sense of how bad the AI was.  I admit I am not the biggest fan of RTS games to begin with, so if I have to fight my own units AI on top of that, it makes it even more difficult to look forward to.

Perhaps fans of the original game will be more forgiving. I actually didn't realize ahead of time this was a remake of a classic game.  Somehow I missed this the first time around.  Now I wish I had missed it the second time as well.

This is a pre completion review so I focus on game mechanics and overall playability intead of the campaign.

Overall the game is made by the people who worked on open world simulators before and it shows similarities with ARMA and so on. Load times are pleasingly short (only good thing), graphics look decent by yesterdays standards and lighting and weather effects are not too demanding so one can say the game wont get any uglier when you turn down high graphics.

The settings are alright graphics wise, key remapping is standard simulator stuff with reminders of what key functions will be overwritten so it is best to keep the standard controls on. MOUSE settings are atrocious but at least you can fiddle with horizontal and vertical sensitivity which is good to compensate for the forever accelerated mouse view.

Biggest thing against this simulator is the fact that it is far from a simulator. HOORAY for Bohemia stooping to these caveman standards of gameplay.

To go about your business you equip your units with gear that gets unlocked during campaign or randomly after taking an island ... that's right. reviewText:
As a player who remembers the original Carrier Command, this game seems like a surprising step back in terms of scope, but it is, fundamentally, quite good fun.

Some bugs exist, but can mostly be worked around.  The walrus pathfinding is still unreliable, although nowhere near as bad as it was at launch.  You'll also spend most of your time flying Mantas, rather than driving Walruses as the Mantas have much greater tactical flexibility; if you're wanting to play a drive-and-shoot game, this may not be a great choice.

On the other hand, the Mantas handle well, the islands are fun to crack and the unit loadout and upgrade paths are enjoyable to work with.  There's a certain satisfaction to driving a Walrus around armed with flak cannons simply obliterating anything you can get into your crosshairs.  Choosing whether to arm your mantas with missiles to make your life easier, or rockets for greater firepower, but necessitating greater handling skills (which isn't easy when you're dodging missiles yourself) is a choice worth making and if you make a poor choice, you'll find out quickly (and possibly painfully) enough.

To do well, you'll have to work out approach and escape routes as often enough you'll find yourself sneaking around a building corner to come face to face with a flak-armed Walrus, having to flee, dropping down to wave-skimming height with Hell's fury erupting around and behind you as you limp back to the carrier to repair and try again.  There's a frisson to these moments that is well worth experiencing.

Is it worth the full asking price of ¬£20?  Maybe not, but it's definitely worth playing, and one run through of the Campaign (linear story) and the Strategy Game (non-linear island hopping campaign) will keep you entertained for a fair few hours.  If you're willing to add mods, that might make the Strategy Game worth playing through a second time, but basically all they'll do is increase the difficulty (and remove some possible exploits) as opposed to introducing anything really new.

There's a free demo available, so try the game out and work out what price you think the game is worth.  There are plenty of newer games with more bugs and less polish being given far better reviews than this received upon its release.

8/10 - Would fly backwards into trees again.

reviewText:
Carrier Command is evidently a revamp of a classic 80's game that I wasn't around for. All I know is that this game is worth at least $10, $15 at most.

Campaign is basically just a huge tutorial. The Strategy Game is where it's at. Your carrier is placed on a random island controlled by the U.E.C. (Basically N.A.T.O.) or a neutral island. The enemy carrier is place on a random island controlled by the Asians or a neutral island. And it's off to the races.

Each carrier can hold 4 amphibious assault vehicles and 4 aircraft,  As the game progresses, you'll unlock more tech.

The idea is to either destroy the enemy Carrier, capture all islands, or both, depending on your setup. What makes the game sweet is that, while a strategy game, you can also control any of your units, including the carrier itself, while still being able to issue orders to other units. It's a hybrid, really, and fairly well done.

All in all, take it for what it's worth, there's a demo, try it out.

reviewText:
Back in the late 1980's, there was a game called Carrier Command available on the Atari system in 3.5inch floppy disk format. I was only 4 or 5 years old at the time, so I wasn't able to fully grasp the concept of the game at that time. But I do remember enjoying many hours of Atari gaming with the original Carrier Command. So when I came across Gaea Mission on Steam, I just had to check it out.

The playable demo did not disappoint. As the commander of a large carrier (hence the name, Carrier Command), it is the player's job to colonise numerous islands scattered within a vast archipelago. These islands can then be used to perform research and production of superior weapons and technologies that can be used to enhance the combat effectiveness of the carrier and support vehicles. Meanwhile, the opponent is doing exactly the same thing. War is inevitable, it's just a matter of how well prepared and equipped you are vs your opponent, when the time comes.

Support vehicles consist of four aircraft (Manta) and four amphibious vehicles (Walrus). Each can be kitted out with various upgrades such as armour, weapons, sensors etc, some of which are only available for either Manta or Walrus. For example, Capsules enable the player to comandeer islands and can only be fitted to the Walrus. Similarly, the Hook allows the Manta to pick up and transport Walrus vehicles, therefore it can only be fitted to the Manta.

Most computers may be out of their depth trying to run Gaea Mission on maximum settings, but a high-end gaming machine will have no problem. Having tried all the settings however, I can say that the graphics are still very attractive on the lowest setting. Either way, there is so much more depth to this game than I am able to portray with a brief review. So if you're a fan of the RTS genre and/or you've played the original Carrier Command and/or you fancy exploring uninhabited islands and/or you like my review, I highly recommend Gaea Mission.

A game that's about island-hop-conquering an ocean full of enemy bases from an advanced carrier that acts as a mobile base, allows you complete control over your units, research, construction, and even allows you to run around in first person?  Sounds awesome right?  Well... it's not.

Sure, the game looks great and the world you're in is huge, but there's just too much wrong to enjoy any of it.

Until this game gets some serious patch updates, I can't possibly recommend this to anyone.

UPDATE 6-20-14: This game is still broken as hell.  Yeah, they've patched pathfinding, terrain clipping and some of the dumber AI behavior, but the rest of the game is still abysmal.  The core problem is that the game requires you to heavily rely upon the AI's scripting and for your vehicles to be at least half-way competent at navigation and combat, but they are incapable of handling themselves and will require you to personally assume control in almost every situation.  So in reality, it's not an RTS or even team-based game in any way; it's just you jumping from vehicle to vehicle to avoid getting them killed and fighting every battle for them, or driving them around the more complicated terrain cause they all got stuck.

Avoid this, at all costs, even if it's going for a dollar.  It's just not worth your time.

reviewText:
This is a pre completion review so I focus on game mechanics and overall playability intead of the campaign.

Overall the game is made by the people who worked on open world simulators before and it shows similarities with ARMA and so on. Load times are pleasingly short (only good thing), graphics look decent by yesterdays standards and lighting and weather effects are not too demanding so one can say the game wont get any uglier when you turn down high graphics.

The settings are alright graphics wise, key remapping is standard simulator stuff with reminders of what key functions will be overwritten so it is best to keep the standard controls on. MOUSE settings are atrocious but at least you can fiddle with horizontal and vertical sensitivity which is good to compensate for the forever accelerated mouse view.

Biggest thing against this simulator is the fact that it is far from a simulator. It just dumbs down anything you know from ARMA and makes it controllable with a gamepad (hurr durr thats why theres an extra gamepad settings menu). The squad selection is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and requires you to HOLD Ctrl + 2 trough 9 to select specifically those units which will get orders. Otherwise EVERY unit will receive the quick command orders from the circle selector which you activate with the Space key... oh yeah NO JUMPING, NEVER! This also means, no loopings, dodging or any other stuff you can perform in ANY real simulator be it on foot, in a vehicle or aircraft... HOORAY for Bohemia stooping to these caveman standards of gameplay.

To go about your business you equip your units with gear that gets unlocked during campaign or randomly after taking an island ... that's right. You do not control the building process on any of your islands except what special purpose it should focus on (ressources, manufacturing, defence and one single central stockpile island or the island which will  spawn anything you put into production queue)
Defence function is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•T since it gives you only a few more hours before a well equipped enemy carrier cleans house.

BTT: You set waypoints and wait for the brainded AI to steer your units on automatically chosen paths in a single formation which is always a line / convoy... another dumbed down feature but it is probably better because pathfinding is  a real ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•! Sometimes you forget to put the command into execute mode and suddenly realize that your spearhead attack unit is alone against a whole base. Autoaim is strong in this game (because its the future ... oh no because it is Bohemia and they cannot ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing program merciful AI if their life depended on it... EVERYTHING has AUTOAIM except the player controlled unit.

You have to LOOK at the target, check if the reticle is YELLOW (wtf y u no red?) and select the ATTACK order from the cricle menu AND press E for execute... then you watch how awkwardly misplaced gunfire does magical one hit kills or the laser beams get bent in a weird way around your cockpit and magically do damage.

The biggest GRIPE I have with the weapons is that they are pretty useless even if you have the superior guns. The AI is too dumb to attack from afar (no comparison to ARMA Tank crews) and the early AA weapons suck ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• because the swarm of bullets you keep spewing is 1 pixel OFF so the target just laughs and keeps dodging and attacking you.

The balancing is overall ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•!

While on foot in the campaign you can take a lot of shots from enemy droids and infantry but piloting a vehicle or aircraft those droids become a real pain unless you manage to take em out from afar or slam into them. A small group can easily bring down half if not more armor depending on their weapons.

HEAT turrets... oh god why!? There is a fire and forget weapon for almost anything. HEAT slugs can oneshot any light armored tank and the AUTOAIM can lead to your whole platoon to be wiped by a SINGLE UNIT! This means most of the time you will have to reload a save (if you saved at all or restart the island since you wont get reinforcements in time to continue where you left off.

Your carrier is equipped with a front turret that is made out of the weakest armor in the game. One hit from another plasma turret will wipe it out and the reconstruction takes a LOT of time.

The enemy carrier can OUTRUN your aircrafts... thats right. The ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• naval units in this game are as fast as a VTOL and once they are out of radar range THEY MAGICALLY DISAPPEAR -.-

Bringing down the enemy carrier is ridiculous. You'll go trough most of your turret ammunition, your idiotic bots can't replenish ammo while the carrier is moving since the pathfinding is TOO DUMB TO LAND on a moving ship (but manually you can do it one by one while flying just above the carrier bay doors)

Basically what you do is switch from map to first person or third person camera behind a turret all thetime.
To take out turrets you switch to manual control, to kill anything up close you switch back to map and do the trategy game thing (select units then click target) ALL the while the CURSOR moves like it has parkinson disease making you feel like the game runs on 10 FPS ... it is the pinacle of awkward having to manually select everything with mouse acceleration and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• cursor design that (3 times bigger than the unit you want to select (TO APPEAL TO the console RTS crowd ... WTF BOHEMIA?)

TL;DR
GAME IS PLAYABLE but at the same time a HUGE UNFULLFILING TIME WASTING EXPERIENCE thanks to the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•iest simulator controls ever from the bunch who specialized in making military and squad sims ...
They should be ashamed of themselves for wasting this games potential. It could be much less frustrating.
